content:
ASIA-PAC

US Commerce Secretary Ross said China came to negotiations with the US due to the substantial tariffs imposed on it and that tariffs are accelerating the hollowing out of Chinese supply chains with companies moving production elsewhere. (Newswires)

China Ministry of Rural Affairs said China has not agreed to the USD 50bln of agricultural purchases figure but do plan on buying a "considerable" amount although "many things" must happen before the purchases, according to Fox's Lawrence. (Fox Business)

  • Chinese New Yuan Loans (CNY)(Sep) 1690B vs. Exp. 1400B (Prev. 1210B). (Newswires)
  • Chinese Aggregate Financing (CNY)(Sep) 2270B vs. Exp. 1900B (Prev. 1980B)
  • Chinese M2 Money Supply (Sep) Y/Y 8.4% vs. Exp. 8.2% (Prev. 8.2%)
  • Indian Trade Balance Govt (USD)(Sep) -10.86B vs. Exp. -12.85B (Prev. -13.45B). (Newswires)
  • Indian Exports (USD)(Sep) 26.03B (Prev. 26.13B)
  • Indian Imports (USD)(Sep) 36.89B (Prev. 39.58B)
  • New Zealand GDT Price Change +0.5% (Prev. 0.2%) and Whole Milk Powder Change 0.0% (Prev. -0.2%). (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

There were initial source reports that EU & UK negotiators are reportedly closing in on a draft Brexit deal contingent on PM Johnson receiving DUP support and that a Brexit draft treaty could be published on Wednesday morning according to both senior UK and EU sources, while reports also stated that a Brexit deal text is taking shape with negotiations continuing but could go on through the notional midnight deadline in order to provide it to EU27 meeting on Wednesday. However, other reports stated that EU leaders see a 3-month extension as far more realistic than getting a Brexit deal done and UK government insiders were later said to be cautioning that talk of an imminent deal is “premature” as there are still hurdles to overcome. (Newswires/RTE/BBC/ITV)

UK PM Johnson spokesperson confirmed that a deal must be reached by the end of Tuesday, while the spokesperson added that the PM is aware of time constraints and wants to make progress ASAP. (Newswires)

UK PM Johnson has no intention of trying to repeal the Benn Act and will send a letter under these terms, while he will send a 2nd letter with the contents dependent on whether a deal is agreed, nearly agreed or all bets are off, according to ITV's Peston. (ITV)

EU Chief Brexit Negotiator Barnier told the EU27 that the latest Brexit proposals from Britain are not enough and that there needs to be an agreement by the end of today, if this is not completed then he may have to recommend further negotiations. Furthermore, Barnier tweeted that talks are difficult but believes an agreement is still possible, while EU diplomats noted that Barnier sees 3 scenarios ahead which include a deal tonight, extension or a 'breakdown'. (Newswires/Twitter)

The EU will call another emergency Brexit summit on either 28th or 29th October if negotiators fail to meet tonight's deadline of midnight to replace the Irish backstop, according to sources. (Telegraph)

DUP said gaps remain before it will support any fresh Brexit agreement following meeting with PM Johnson and reportedly will not back a Brexit deal if UK PM Johnson makes more concessions to the EU according to a source, while it is said to be ruling out a customs border down the Irish Sea which is precisely the compromise thought to have been made by UK PM Johnson. In related news, Irish PM Varadkar said DUP will wait for a final deal before making a judgement, while he added initial indicators are that we are making progress and moving in the right direction although at the moment it is unclear if we can have a deal in time for the summit. (Newswires/Daily Mirror/Huffington Post)

UK ERG Leader Baker said he is still optimistic a tolerable deal can be made which he could vote for. (Newswires)

Irish Foreign Minister Coveney said negotiating teams made progress, albeit slow and that a deal is difficult but possible, while he added it is also possible to move beyond summit and continue talks next week but at the moment there are no plans for an emergency summit. (Newswires)

Germany warned that Brexit will need to be delayed until next year even if EU and British negotiators agree a new deal over the next 12 hours. (The Times)

BoE Governor Carney said they can cut rates close to, but slightly above 0% if this is required, while there were also comments from BoE's Vlieghe that the global outlook has deteriorated again since July and the scenario of an entrenched Brexit uncertainty is likely to require some stimulus. Furthermore, Vlieghe continues to see UK effective lower bound close to but above zero and stated there is not much more room for gilt yields to fall regarding possibility of future QE. (Newswires)

 

  • UK Employment Change (Aug) -56k vs. Exp. 23k (Prev. 31k). (Newswires)
  • UK ILO Unemployment Rate (Aug) 3.9% vs. Exp. 3.8% (Prev. 3.8%)
  • UK Avg Wk Earnings 3M (Aug) Y/Y 3.8% vs. Exp. 4.0% (Prev. 4.0%, Rev. 3.9%)
  • UK Avg Earnings (Ex-Bonus) (Aug) 3.8% vs. Exp. 3.7% (Prev. 3.8%, Rev. 3.9%)
  • German ZEW Economic Sentiment (Oct) -22.8 vs. Exp. -27.0 (Prev. -22.5)

 

GEOPOLITICS 

SDC official said Turkish backed forces are attacking Kobani and kidnapping civilians despite Turkey President Erdogan’s commitment to US President Trump that he wouldn't attack the town. There were also comments from Turkey President Erdogan that the country can never declare a ceasefire in northern Syria and that he is not worried about US sanctions. (Newswires/Twitter)

US State Department official said the US is planning to raise sanctions on Turkey if a resolution to the crisis is not found, while it was also reported that US Senator Graham will introduce a bill on Thursday sanctioning Turkey for Syria incursion and that US prosecutors charged Turkey's Halkbank in regards to alleged Iran sanctions violations. (Newswires)

 

US

Fed Discount Rate Minutes stated a narrow majority wanted to leave the discount rate unchanged citing strong labour market and inflation near 2% target in which Boston, New York, Philadelphia, Richmond, Cleveland, Atlanta and Kansas City voted to leave the discount rate unchanged, while Minneapolis, Chicago, Dallas and San Francisco voted to cut the rate. (Newswires)

Fed's Bullard (Voter, Dissenter, Dove) said rates are going to zero and that forward guidance, as well as QE are still in the Fed's toolbox in the case of an ordinary recession. (Newswires)

Fed's Daly (Non-Voter, Dove) said news on the US economy is largely positive, growth in jobs is strong and consumer spending is healthy but the Fed is still yet to hit its inflation target, while she added trade uncertainty and slower global growth have started to 'gust'. Daly also suggested that 2 rate cuts this year should help sustain the expansion despite the headwinds and growth in work force without a rise in productivity will drag on the economic future. (Newswires) 

 

MARKET RECAP

Britannia ruled the flows as reports of a Brexit draft deal being near to completion saw moves into risk assets - major equity bourses, yields, activity currencies and crude had a mid-session rally, whilst XAU, DX and JPY declined. China optimism had pared back further as it announced it wanted further tariff reprieve before it made agricultural purchases, singing to the tune that the “Phase 1 deal” was no done deal. As US participants returned from Columbus Day they were greeted with the first day of major US financials (JPM, C, WFC, GS) reporting their Q3 earnings – GS being the noted underperformer with its pinnacle IB unit taking a hit on revenue, with JPM being a stellar exemplar for the sector, beating its EPS and Revenue estimates, with solid growth in its NII/NIM. UnitedHealth Group (UNH) surged after beating earnings estimates whilst guiding FY19 EPS above consensus. JPMorgan (JPM) was a top performer on a beat on top and bottom line, with growth in its NII. Conversely, Goldman Sachs (GS) fell short of expectations on top and bottom line with a 15% decline in IB revenue, seeing it lag the wider sector. Citigroup (C) disappointed on its NII/NIM and posted a 4% decline in its equity unit revenue, although beat on EPS and Revenue. Wells Fargo (WFC) posted a fall in its NIM/NII but caught tailwinds after announcing in its conference call it would be lowering its deposit rates. Charles Schwab (SCHW) caught a bid after beating top and bottom line estimates. Nvidia (NVDA) surged on a PT rise at BofA/ML, citing the chipmaker’s position as poised to benefit from innovation in AI. Consumer Staples (PG, CAG, YUM, CL) traded in the red amid flows out of defensive names. Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) beat earnings estimates whilst raising guidance although did exclude litigation expenses from its results. S&P 500 1% at 2996, NASDAQ-100 1.3% at 7943, Dow Jones 0.9% at 27025.

T-Notes reopened after the long weekend following Columbus Day closures on Monday. The complex sold off throughout the session since the US equity cash open, as it took a leg lower on reports that the UK and EU are close to a draft deal, which saw global debt sell off. At settlement, yields were approximately 1bp higher across the curve, with the long end almost 2bp higher. On the overnight repo operations, NY Fed accepted (USD) 67.6bln out of the 75bln offered, however demand was expected to be high as today was coupon settlement day, additionally, the Fed has now begun purchasing T-Bills at an initial clip of USD 60bln a month, as it announced last week. US T-Notes (Z9) settled 14+ ticks lower at 129.24+.

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 15th October 2019: Brexit deal hopes sees risk asset rally
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

US MARKET WRAP 15th October 2019: Brexit deal hopes sees risk asset rally

 

* SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries down, Dollar down, Crude down

* REAR VIEW: Brexit draft deal near completion, although hurdles remain; China requests further tariff relief before Ag. purchases; Financials begin Q3 earnings, strong JPM, weak GS; IMF cuts growth outlook for 5th time

* UPCOMING: Data: UK CPI, EZ CPI (Final), US Retail Sales & Business Inventories, Canadian CPI, APIs. Speakers: Fed's Evans & Brainard, ECB's Lane, BoE's Carney & Haldane. Supply: Germany. Earnings: BAC, ABT, PYPL, NFLX, IBM, ASML

 

* MARKET WRAP: Britannia ruled the flows as reports of a Brexit draft deal being near to completion saw moves into risk assets - major equity bourses, yields, activity currencies and crude had a mid-session rally, whilst XAU, DX and JPY declined. China optimism had pared back further as it announced it wanted further tariff reprieve before it made agricultural purchases, singing to the tune that the “Phase 1 deal” was no done deal. As US participants returned from Columbus Day they were greeted with the first day of major US financials (JPM, C, WFC, GS) reporting their Q3 earnings – GS being the noted underperformer with its pinnacle IB unit taking a hit on revenue, with JPM being a stellar exemplar for the sector, beating its EPS and Revenue estimates, with solid growth in its NII/NIM; participants look to BAC earnings on Wednesday. The IMF, unsurprisingly, cut its world demand growth forecast (the 5th time in 2019), which was attributed to the energy complex’s underperformance, where Brexit relief did little to shape investor concerns of the slowing global outlook.

* BREXIT: The EU and UK were reported to have been closing in on a draft Brexit deal which would be contingent on DUP support – sparking a risk asset rally – where PM Johnson is said to have compromised on a solution containing a customs border down the Irish Sea. Irish PM Varadkar said the DUP were to wait until the deal proposal had been finalised before passing judgement, although the DUP did say that the deal would need to work for all and ruled out a customs border down the Irish Sea. The success of the deal passing through Parliament, with DUP’s support, will centre around how much the deal resembles the previously rejected Northern Ireland-only backstop; although some had suggested the Brexiteer MPs could be more supportive of a deal this time around due to the fact some hold more central government positions now, and therefore, would like to see their government succeed - although this is just speculation. Negotiations on a draft are said to be continuing into the night, which could go beyond the notional midnight deadline in order for it to be provided to the EU27 tomorrow.

* US/CHINA TRADE: There was some more walking back of optimism over US/China 'phase one' deal, with sources reporting that China wanted tariffs removed before it committed to further agricultural purchases (which US President Trump announced on Friday). FBN’s Lawrence also cited a Chinese official from the Ministry of Rural Affairs saying China had not agreed to the USD 50bln figure for agricultural purchases, but do plan on the purchase of a “considerable” amount. It is another sign that the 'deal' is merely an in principle de-escalation of tensions, which has seen the 15th October tariffs suspended, along with the vague commitments made by China; the news also comes on the back of Monday's reports that China wanted further talks before it was ready to sign the phase one deal, which was reiterated on Tuesday, which casts some scepticism of the proposed sign-off by Trump and Chinese President Xi at the APEC summit in mid-November.

* CLOSING LEVELS: S&P 500 1% at 2996, NASDAQ-100 1.3% at 7943, Dow Jones 0.9% at 27025

* SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary 1%, Consumer Staples -0.4%, Energy 0.4%, Financials 1.3%, Health Care 1.8%, Industrials 0.8%, Information Technology 1.1%, Materials 0.7%, Telecommunication Services 1.6%, Utilities -0.3%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: UnitedHealth Group (UNH) surged after beating earnings estimates whilst guiding FY19 EPS above consensus. JPMorgan (JPM) was a top performer on a beat on top and bottom line, with growth in its NII. Conversely, Goldman Sachs (GS) fell short of expectations on top and bottom line with a 15% decline in IB revenue, seeing it lag the wider sector. Citigroup (C) disappointed on its NII/NIM and posted a 4% decline in its equity unit revenue, although beat on EPS and Revenue. Wells Fargo (WFC) posted a fall in its NIM/NII but caught tailwinds after announcing in its conference call it would be lowering its deposit rates. Charles Schwab (SCHW) caught a bid after beating top and bottom line estimates. Nvidia (NVDA) surged on a PT rise at BofA/ML, citing the chipmaker’s position as poised to benefit from innovation in AI. Consumer Staples (PG, CAG, YUM, CL) traded in the red amid flows out of defensive names. Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) beat earnings estimates whilst raising guidance although did exclude litigation expenses from its results.

* CHINA SEPTEMBER CPI: Consumer prices rose at a rate of 3.0% Y/Y in September (prev. from 2.8%, consensus 2.9%); PPI fell to -1.2% Y/Y in September (prev. -0.8%). Swine flu contributed again to higher pork prices, resulting in food inflation firming, despite base effects. Pantheon Macroeconomics said overall, inflation looks likely to peak at a little below 4.0% in Q1 next year, even assuming swine flu is brought under control. "That will worry the authorities, but the policy response will focus more on supply, rather than trying to curb demand. In short, the PBoC will continue to be focused on PPI deflation." The PPI signal was in keeping with that of the PMIs, with commodities and processing weighing on the headline, with chemicals and processing of ferrous metals the main drags. "Headline deflation should soon start to trough, aided by favourable base effects thanks to the drop in commodities prices in Q4 last year," Pantheon writes, "nevertheless, the authorities will remain in easing mode well into next year, and we continue to expect a rate corridor cut of at least 10bp this year." Other analysts talking the data -- where CPI is rising on higher pork prices, and PPI is slowing on economic weakness -- is not a particularly encouraging combination.

* DEMOCRAT DEBATE: The fourth democrat debate will take place aftermarket, and polls show Elizabeth Warren is taking the lead, as Joe Biden becomes mired in controversy over his family's dealings with Ukraine while he was Vice President.

* FED: Fed’s Bullard (Voter, Dove, Dissenter) reiterated that trade and other risks remain high and that the rate decisions are taken meeting by meeting. Bullard also commented on recession probability models, saying there are “elevated” (in the minutes several policymakers noted statistical models of a recession in the medium term did increase notably). If there was an ordinary recession, Bullard reiterated that rates could go to zero, forward guidance and QE are also in the toolbox, if needed. On its repo-facility, he hopes for it to launch in 6 months. Fed’s Daly (Non-Voter) spoke to the US economy’s news being largely positive and strong growth in the labour market.

* IMF: The IMF cut its global GDP growth by 0.2% in 2019 to 3%, and cut its 2019 global GDP growth to 3.4% from 3.5%. US global growth was also cut in 2019 to 2.4% from 2.6%, and 2020 US GDP growth, however, was increased to 2.1% from 1.9% in July. China’s GDP was cut in 2019 to 6.1% (Prev 6.2%) and cut in 2020 to 5.8% from 6%. The IMF noted that trade war could result in China’s GDP to fall 2% in the near term, and 1% in the long term. For the US, IMF says GDP could fall 0.6% in both short and long term. The Fund also noted that risks are skewed to the downside due to Trade Wars, Brexit, Manufacturing and a falling risk appetite.  Trade Wars will result in a cumulative 0.8% fall in global GDP by 2020, adding if both October and December tariffs do not take effect, this decline would be smaller. On the UK, IMF expects a no deal Brexit would reduce UK GDP by 3%. Overall, the IMF does not see a recession but sees risks from having low interest rates for a prolonged period of time.

WTI (X9) SETTLES USD 0.78 LOWER AT USD 52.81/BBL; BRENT (Z9) SETTLES USD 0.61 LOWER AT USD 58.74/BBL: Energy benchmarks were lower with extended China trade concerns on top of an IMF global growth downgrade (although unsurprising given its lagging characteristics). OPEC Secretary General Barkindo said OPEC+ compliance stands at 136% - less than the sources report of 200% on Monday – adding that the physical market is relatively tight (although Brent and WTI time calendar spreads tell otherwise recently, displaying falling backwardation as the Saudi Aramco attacks in September fade from the limelight). Not alleviating poor demand concerns was sources suggesting China’s Sinopec is considering a reduction of crude imports in December due to the surge in shipping/freight rates. The API is to report its US energy inventory data on Wednesday evening, ahead of the EIA official release on Thursday, which are both delayed one day due to the US holiday on Monday; current expectations see crude stocks +2.8mln bbls, distillates -2.2mln bbls and gasoline -1.4mln bbls, whilst Genscape sees Cushing stocks +0.72mln bbls.

* US T-NOTE (Z9) SETTLED 14+ TICKS LOWER AT 129.24+: T-Notes reopened after the long weekend following Columbus Day closures on Monday. The complex sold off throughout the session since the US equity cash open, as it took a leg lower on reports that the UK and EU are close to a draft deal, which saw global debt sell off. At settlement, yields were approximately 1bp higher across the curve, with the long end almost 2bp higher. On the overnight repo operations, NY Fed accepted (USD) 67.6bln out of the 75bln offered, however demand was expected to be high as today was coupon settlement day, additionally, the Fed has now begun purchasing T-Bills at an initial clip of USD 60bln a month, as it announced last week.

* CHINA MONEY GROWTH: M2 money supply rose further to +8.4% Y/Y, beating the expected +8.2% which would have been the same pace as the prior. ING note the rising municipal government issuance of bonds for infrastructure projects, which attributed a CNY 2trln increase and it believes will continue to grow by a further CNY 1trln in Q4. The bank sees debt continuing to rise amid the US-China trade war with infrastructure underpinning that growth.

* ECB: The Dutch National Bank's financial stability report warned that prolonged low interest rates constitute one of the major risks to financial stability internationally, noting that financial conditions have been accommodative for several years now, reducing incentives for bringing down debts, and can lead to distorted pricing in financial markets, which could cause asset price bubbles. The DNB also said that persistently low interest rates was weighing heavily on pension funds and life insurers and could incite them to take additional risks.

* BOE: BoE Governor Carney said the BoE can cut rates close to, but slightly above 0%, if it is required. Vlieghe also noted that he continues to see the UK effective lower bound close to but above zero. Vileghe did note since July the global outlook has deteriorated again, adding a scenario of entrenched Brexit uncertainty is likely to require some stimulus. On future QE, he said there is not much more room for gilt yields to fall. Vlieghe noted slack in the UK economy is probably increasing again, which has a significant impact on the policy outlook, adding rate setters cannot respond to bad news as effectively as good news, which should therefore make them patient on rate hikes.

* BOJ: Former BoJ executive director Hideo Hayakawa said the central bank would only loosen policy further if it was in conjunction with the government to tackle the risk of falling price momentum due to an economic deterioration. Hayakawa added that markets were wrong to assume the BoJ will simply cut rates following the Fed's lead. He also argued that the JPY was not critically strong, and therefore the BoJ would not ramp up easing at the 31st October policy meeting, unless the government has plans for an extra stimulus package.

* RBA MINUTES: The October meeting minutes had two important features, Westpac says; the first relates the conclusion, where the central bank stated that "the Board would continue to monitor developments, including in the labour market, and was prepared to ease monetary policy further, if needed" -- similar to the conclusion used in September prior to a further rate cut. Westpac says that it was expecting the conclusion to the October minutes to look like the August conclusion, which would have indicated that the Board intended to pause in November as they gathered more information; but that conclusion was not used, noting that the conclusion in October, "was prepared to ease", is not as strong as the September conclusion "would ease" - It is like the July conclusion, with no strong commitment, and allowing some flexibility. But the bank found it surprising that the Board did not choose to close off the option of another move so soon after October. The second feature was the detailed discussion of the decision to cut rates in October, and a discussion on why lower rates could still be effective. The minutes noted that it was the level of rates rather than the change that was the important determinant, Westpac explains, and that holding back rate cuts in anticipation of a negative shock was not the best policy, instead it was better to take swift action so that the economy would be better placed to absorb a negative shock. There was also a discussion on whether low rates might hit confidence, though the minutes were less conclusive on that question. "There is no doubt that this discussion can be seen as a justification of the decision that was made in October," Westpac writes, "central banks will always provide robust arguments to support their decisions, however, these arguments seem to go beyond merely justifying the decision in October and laying the foundation for even lower rates." The bank notes the lack of discussion on what the ZLB is for rates. Elsewhere, the minutes noted positive developments on exports growth, as well as some aspects of the labour market, though interestingly, the minutes did not confirm the RBA's view that GDP growth in 2020 would be around trend, which Westpac says may imply that the Bank is preparing to lower its GDP forecast for 2020 when it revises them next in November.

* FX: GBP rallied following a report that both EU and UK negotiators were closing in on a draft Brexit deal, trading in a range from 1.2604 – 1.2798, seeing support and resistance at the psychological levels, 1.26 and 1.28, respectively. DXY traded between 98.201 – 98.650 with technicians keeping an eye on the 98.210 Fib retracement level.  The greenback traded slightly lower heading into the Asia session as a strong GBP weighs on the buck, which lost a lot of its ground since the US equity open. Havens were lower following hopeful Brexit news, USDJPY traded between 108.16 and 108.89, as it followed a similar pattern to US 10-year yields, with rate differentials also likely resulting in outflows of JPY. Participants are keeping an eye on the 200dma at 109.06 as their next target if the cross continues to rise. XAU spent the morning just beneath the 1500 level, however as markets took a constructive tone, the precious metal sold off throughout the session back to lows beneath 1480.  CHF was weaker against the buck, however weaker against EUR and GBP. CAD caught a bid on risk appetite pushing USDCAD briefly beneath 1.3200, where it currently flirts around the handle at pixel time. Antipodes both on the backfoot as uncertainties around the Phase 1 deal between the US and China are still alive as sources suggested the Chinese requested a full removal of tariffs in order to spend USD 50bln on agricultural goods, AUDUSD at 67.50 heading into Asia, and NZDUSD trading beneath the 0.63 handle, at 0.6280. TRY outperformed among EMFX currencies as the sanctions on the region were less severe than some had initially thought, however tensions are still high as a US official said the US is planning to raise sanctions on the nation. MXN was flat, ZAR weaker and BRL underperformed against the buck heading into the US cash close.

subject: WTI (X9) settles USD 0.78 lower at USD 52.81/bbl; Brent (Z9) settles USD 0.61 lower at USD 58.74/bbl
analysis_details: Energy benchmarks were lower with extended China trade concerns on top of an IMF global growth downgrade (although unsurprising given its lagging characteristics). OPEC Secretary General Barkindo said OPEC+ compliance stands at 136% - less than the sources report of 200% on Monday – adding that the physical market is relatively tight (although Brent and WTI time calendar spreads tell otherwise recently, displaying falling backwardation as the Saudi Aramco attacks in September fade from the limelight). Not alleviating poor demand concerns was sources suggesting China’s Sinopec is considering a reduction of crude imports in December due to the surge in shipping/freight rates. The API is to report its US energy inventory data on Wednesday evening, ahead of the EIA official release on Thursday, which are both delayed one day due to the US holiday on Monday; current expectations see crude stocks +2.8mln bbls, distillates -2.2mln bbls and gasoline -1.4mln bbls, whilst Genscape sees Cushing stocks +0.72mln bbls.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Pound regains Brexit bravado, but Kiwi and Aussie remain bashful
content:
GBP

A circa 200 pip range in Cable and big figure+ for Eur/Gbp hardly begins to tell the full story for Sterling on another day full of Brexit headlines comprising positive vibes, media jibes and an array of doubters questioning whether the UK and EU are any closer to reaching a deal or have hardly made more progress. In short, the main man in Brussels, Barnier, compounded rising optimism over a breakthrough, but subsequently doused hopes by stating that UK proposals still fall short of the mark. However, he remained hopeful that an accord could still be forged in time for this week’s Summit and while many believe a further Article 50 extension is more likely (even though the EU may yet call another pre-October 31 meeting on the 28th), the latest word, but no doubt far from final came via sources saying the 2 sides are nearly at the point of a draft agreement, ‘fingers crossed’. The upshot, Cable is now nudging 1.2800 after breezing through the 200 DMA (1.2713) and eclipsing a recent 1.2785 high, while Eur/Gbp has breached Fib support (0.8661) on the way down to almost 0.8625). For the record, UK data in the form of jobs/wages hardly caused a STIR amidst the Brexit barrage, but was weaker than forecast for choice and comments from BoE’s Vlieghe sounded more dovish/downbeat than the MPC’s ongoing gradual and limited tightening chant, but also largely dismissed.

NZD/AUD

The Kiwi and Aussie were undermined to an extent by more uncertainty about the terms and conditions surrounding Phase 1 of the US-China trade deal that emerged via headlines suggesting that Beijing may not be able to meet its pledge to buy up to Usd50 bn US farm goods per annum without lifting counter tariffs. However, the Antipodean Dollars were already on the back foot after RBA minutes reiterating the low rates form an extended period mantra with an easing bias if the OCR needs to be lowered further, but Aud/Usd and Aud/Nzd both held relatively firm around 0.6750 and 1.0750 respectively to leave Nzd/Usd languishing under 0.6300 ahead of NZ Q3 inflation data and not gleaning much direction from mixed GDT auction prices.

CAD/EUR/CHF/JPY

The aforementioned Brexit news has had a profound knock-on effect and widespread impact on risk sentiment of the significantly bullish/upbeat kind, with Usd/Cad breaking lower to retest 1.3200 and Eur/Usd rebounding firmly through 1.1000, in stark contrast to Usd/Chf and Usd/Jpy that that surged through recent pinnacles and upside tech/psychological resistance towards parity and 109.00 respectively.

USD

The Greenback was mainly hostage to moves elsewhere given a sparse US agenda and nothing new from Fed dissenter and 50 bp rate cut advocate Bullard. Nevertheless, the 

DXY 

was subject to volatile trade within 98.201-650 parameters and from a chart perspective a close above or sub-98.210 (Fib retracement level) could be key.

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 15th October 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European indices are firmer this morning, though sentiment has been impacted by US-China rhetoric
  • Reports indicate China will struggle to purchase USD 50bln of US agri products annually, unless retaliatory tariffs are removed
  • Mixed comments from EU’s Barnier stating that a Brexit deal is possible this week although sources note that the latest proposals are not enough
  • DXY is mixed vs. G10 peers, with GBP and JPY outperforming and the debt complex is firmer thus far
  • Looking ahead highlights include US NY Fed Manufacturing, NZ CPI, Fed Discount Minutes, IMF World Economic Outlook, Fed’s Bostic, George & Daly, BoE’s Vlieghe, US Coupon Settlement
  • Earnings: JP Morgan, Wells Fargo, Goldman Sachs, Citigroup

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mixed following the lacklustre lead from Wall St where the recent US-China trade optimism was tempered by discrepancies in language between the sides and with China wanting more discussions before signing the deal, while looming earnings added to the tentativeness as the large US banks are to begin announcing Q3 results today. ASX 200 (+0.2%) was choppy with the index pressured by underperformance in the commodity-related sectors and Nikkei 225 (+1.9%) outperformed as it played catch up on return from the extended weekend with Japanese officials willing to consider an additional budget for the typhoon recovery if required. Hang Seng (Unch.) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.6%) were indecisive after the trade exhilaration faded, with the HKMA’s announcement of a countercyclical capital buffer reduction and influx of CNY 40bln from the PBoC’s previously announced targeted RRR cut, doing little to spur risk appetite. The latest inflation figures from China were also somewhat inconclusive as CPI topped estimates to print its highest since 2013 although PPI declined at its fastest pace in more than 3 years. Finally, 10yr JGBs traded subdued as demand was dampened amid the strength in Japanese stocks but with downside also restricted by the BoJ’s presence in the market for JPY 1.21tln of JGBs heavily concentrated in 1yr-10yr maturities.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position, although it was noted that CNY 40bln was being released from the previously announced targeted RRR cut. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0708 vs. Exp. 7.0676 (Prev. 7.0725)

Chinese CPI (Sep) Y/Y 3.0% vs. Exp. 2.9% (Prev. 2.8%); highest since 2013. Chinese PPI (Sep) Y/Y -1.2% vs. Exp. -1.2% (Prev. -0.8%); steepest decline since 2016.

China's MOFCOM states that Chinese firms have, based on demand, purchased some US agricultural products. China will accelerate the purchase of US agricultural products., CNBC's Yoon citing a Foreign Ministry Spokesman (Newswires/Twitter)

China will struggle to purchase USD 50bln of US related farm goods annually, unless it removes retaliatory tariffs on American products., according to sources. (Newswires)

US

Fed’s Bullard (Voter, Dissenter, Dove) reiterates that trade and other risks remain high and Fed rate decision are made “meeting by meeting”; models state probability of a recession is elevated. (Newswires)

South Korea and the US are likely to undertake defense cost-sharing discussions next week., according to Yonhap citing Diplomatic Sources. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said the US sanctioned Turkey’s Ministers of Interior, Defence and Energy but added the US will issue license to continue to let Turkey buy fuel and will remove sanctions based on Turkey's actions. (Newswires)

US VP Pence said President Trump spoke with Turkish President Erdogan and asked him to halt incursion into Syria, while Erdogan gave assurance that Turkey will not attack the city of Kobani. Furthermore, Pence said he will visit the region to seek a ceasefire and that no decision has been made on whether the scheduled Trump-Erdogan meeting next month will take place. (Newswires)

UK/EU

EU Chief Brexit Negotiator Barnier told the EU27 that the latest Brexit proposals from Britain are not enough; needs an agreement by the end of today, if this is not completed then he may have to recommend further negotiations., EU Diplomatic Sources. (Newswires)

EU's Chief Brexit Negotiator Barnier says a Brexit deal is still possible this week, high time to turn intentions on Brexit into legal text. Subsequently, reports noted the UK will table fresh proposals to break the Brexit deadlock this morning., RTE’s Connely citing sources. Its’ worth highlighting that since these comments on fresh proposals some rhetoric has highlighted that the UK submitted new proposals last night. (Newswires/Twitter)

Irish Foreign Minister Coveney says negotiating teams made progress, albeit slow, a deal is difficult but possible, it is also possible to move beyond summit and continue talks next week, at the moment no plans for emergency summit. (Newswires)

Irish Foreign Minister Coveney hinted an agreement may not be reachable at the EU summit this week. (RTE) Separately, Brexit deal hopes are reported to have increased as sources in both sides of the channel stated there was cautious optimism that a narrow path to a deal could now be appearing. (Telegraph)

BoE Governor Carney says they can cut rates close to, but slightly above, 0% if this is required. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

A choppy session for European equities thus far [Eurostoxx 50 +0.7%] following on from a mixed Asia-Pac session. European equity futures saw upside heading into the cash open amid refuelled Brexit hopes after EU’s Chief Brexit Negotiator Barnier struck an upbeat tone regarding a potential Brexit deal by the end of the week; although this has been caveated somewhat by EU Diplomatic sources. That said, futures pared back around half of its gains at the open and continued declining with downside exacerbated by source reports that China will struggle to purchase USD 50bln worth of agri goods. Major bourses in the region are ultimately higher, although UK’s FTSE 100 trades flat as exporters bear the brunt of a firmer Sterling, induced by positive comments from various EU lawmakers. Sectors are all in broadly positive territory although the IT sector is somewhat underperforming as Wirecard shares (-18.5%) plumbed the depths after a fresh FT investigation raised prospect of a concerted effort to fake substantial sales and profit at the company. Wirecard has since dismissed the report as “market speculation”. On the flip side, the financial sector fares better as current Brexit optimism spurred gains in domestic banks with Lloyds Banking Group (+3.4%), RBS (+3.4%) Barclays (+2.1%) all at the top of the FTSE 100. Further, the Italian banking sector is propped up by source reports that Italy is mulling reducing the amount of loan losses that banks can deduct from their taxable income next year. Hence the Italian Banking index opened higher by circa. 1% but has since come off of highs. In terms of individual movers, Indivior (+8.0%) shares spiked higher at the open after the Co. boosted its earnings guidance for a second time this year amid a strong performance of its drug used to treat opioid addiction. Meanwhile, Kloeckner & Co. (-14.3%) shares slumped following a downgrade to its profit outlook due to weaker market conditions.

UnitedHealth Group Inc (UNH) Q3 19 (USD): EPS 3.88 (exp. 3.45), Revenue 60.4bln (exp. 60.58bln). FY EPS view 14.90-15.00 (exp. 14.70, prev. 14.70-14.90). (Newswires)

BlackRock Inc (BLK) Q3 19 (USD): EPS 7.15 (exp. 6.71), Revenue 3.69bln (exp. 3.58bln). AUM 6.96tln (prev. 6.44tln). (Newswires)

FX

GBP - Cable seemed destined for or at least drawn towards a hefty option expiry at the 1.2600 strike before another bout of Brexit deal positivity boosted the Pound across the board, and this time from the EU’s chief negotiator Barnier who remains hopeful that a deal can still be struck in time for Thursday-Friday’s Summit, but warns that latest UK proposals remain inadequate. He added that the deadline to reach an agreement is COB today, but separate reports suggest that another meeting could be convened before the current October 31 deadline if needed, while the UK Government believes that the cut-off for this week is actually Wednesday evening. However, the situation remains highly fluid and uncertain, with Sterling hostage to headlines, breaking news and unfolding developments, as Cable fades just ahead of 1.2700 and Eur/Gbp rebounds from just under 0.8700 towards highs of 0.8750.

NZD/AUD - Not much respite for the Antipodean Dollars following further reflection and assessment by China and the US about the state of trade relations and significance of Phase 1 even though Beijing and Washington appear to be more convergent on certain elements of the accord in principle. Indeed, the Kiwi is still capped ahead of 0.6300 awaiting NZ Q3 CPI after the latest GDT auction, while the Aussie remains some way below 0.6800 in wake of RBA minutes underlining guidance for keeping rates low or easing further if required, and with a decent 625 mn expiry at the big figure.

JPY/CAD/EUR/CHF - Comparatively contained trade vs the Greenback again, as the Yen meanders between 108.23-45 and just shy of decent expiry interest residing at 108.00-20 (1.5 bn), while the Loonie is striving to limit losses beyond 1.3240 amidst a deeper retreat in oil prices and Euro remains top heavy into 1.1050, and perhaps also rooted by expiries given 1 bn rolling off just above 1.1000 (1 bn from 1.1015-20). Elsewhere, more soft Swiss inflation inputs via producer/import prices are keeping the Franc depressed just off parity and around 1.1000 against the single currency, as the DXY continues to flit either side of 98.500.

EM - More volatility for the Lira, but a recovery of sorts following US sanctions against Turkey that were perhaps not as severe as many were anticipating. Nevertheless, Usd/Try remains elevated within a 5.8605-9320 range and underpinned on the back of a rise in unemployment plus a big swing in the budget balance from small surplus to onerous deficit.

RBA Minutes from October 1st meeting stated the board judged case for easing at October meeting outweighed arguments against a move and that it is prepared to ease policy further if needed. RBA also reiterated that it is reasonable to expect that an extended period of low rates would be required, while board members noted global trend of lower rates and discussed the possibility rate cuts could have less impact than in past but judged lower rates will still have an effect through AUD. (Newswires)

Norges Bank's Nicolaisen reiterates the September view that rates will likely remain at the current level for the period ahead. (Newswires)

FIXED

A rather gradual and modest bid, but core bonds are tracking US Treasuries higher on latest Chinese headlines suggesting that buying more US agri goods remains contingent on tariff concessions. Bunds, Gilts and 10 year USTs are just off best levels of 172.78, 132.82 and 130-165 respectively vs 172.36, 132.33 and 130-05 at one stage, and probably also unwinding pre-issuance hedges in wake of largely satisfactory if not solid German and UK auctions. Ahead, more scheduled Central Bank speak to perhaps provide distraction and interludes from all the breaking headlines.

COMMODITIES

A downbeat day for WTI and Brent futures thus far as downward pressure resumed as markets tilted towards risk aversion in early EU trade and as optimism surrounding the US-China mini deal fizzles out. Analysts at ING highlight that the ICE Brent Dec/Jan time-spread has also narrowed to a backwardation of around 0.17/bbl vs. 0.77/bbl at the end of September which suggests the “tightness in the prompt market is easing”. In terms of newsflow, OPEC Secretary General Barkindo noted that the physical oil market is relatively tight now and current demand is the market driver. WTI futures took out 53/bbl to the downside and tests 52.50/bbl ahead of the psychological 52.00/bbl mark whilst its Brent counterpart eyes 58/bbl to the downside. As a reminder the weekly API crude inventories have been postponed by a day due to US observing Columbus Day yesterday; as has the EIA release. Elsewhere, gold has climbed off lows amid a turnaround in sentiment and remains in close proximity to 1500/oz vs. an intraday low of around 1488/oz. Copper meanwhile has pulled back during the session, albeit prices remain above 2.62/lb.

OPEC Secretary General Barkindo says OPEC and allies oil output compliance level is at 136%. (Newswires) Source reports recently noted that September’s compliance was in excess of 200%

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 15th October 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets traded mixed following the lacklustre lead from Wall St where the recent US-China trade optimism receded
  • US-China talks are to resume next week and the Phase 1 deal could be wrapped up in November according to Chinese press
  • Brexit deal hopes are reported to have increased as sources in both sides of the channel stated there was cautious optimism, according to the Telegraph
  • US President Trump is to authorise sanctions against Turkish officials, immediately stop negotiations with Turkey on a USD 100bln trade deal and reintroduce steel tariffs back at 50%
  • Looking ahead, highlights include UK Employment, German ZEW, US NY Fed Manufacturing, NZ CPI, Fed Discount Minutes, Fed's Bullard, Bostic, George & Daly, BoE's Carney & Vlieghe, US Coupon Settlement, supply from UK and Germany
  • Earnings: Blackrock, JP Morgan, Wells Fargo, Goldman Sachs, Citigroup, J&J

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mixed following the lacklustre lead from Wall St where the recent US-China trade optimism was tempered by discrepancies in language between the sides and with China wanting more discussions before signing the deal, while looming earnings added to the tentativeness as the large US banks are to begin announcing Q3 results today. ASX 200 (+0.2%) was choppy with the index pressured by underperformance in the commodity-related sectors and Nikkei 225 (+1.9%) outperformed as it played catch up on return from the extended weekend with Japanese officials willing to consider an additional budget for the typhoon recovery if required. Hang Seng (Unch.) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.5%) were indecisive after the trade exhilaration faded, with the HKMA’s announcement of a countercyclical capital buffer reduction and influx of CNY 40bln from the PBoC’s previously announced targeted RRR cut, doing little to spur risk appetite. The latest inflation figures from China were also somewhat inconclusive as CPI topped estimates to print its highest since 2013 although PPI declined at its fastest pace in more than 3 years. Finally, 10yr JGBs traded subdued as demand was dampened amid the strength in Japanese stocks but with downside also restricted by the BoJ’s presence in the market for JPY 1.21tln of JGBs heavily concentrated in 1yr-10yr maturities.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position, although it was noted that CNY 40bln was being released from the previously announced targeted RRR cut. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0708 vs. Exp. 7.0676 (Prev. 7.0725)

 

Chinese CPI (Sep) Y/Y 3.0% vs. Exp. 2.9% (Prev. 2.8%); highest since 2013. Chinese PPI (Sep) Y/Y -1.2% vs. Exp. -1.2% (Prev. -0.8%); steepest decline since 2016.

 

US-China talks are to resume next week and the Phase 1 deal could be wrapped up in November according to China press, while it was also reported that China thinks Phase 1 of the deal was not balanced. (SCMP/CNBC)

 

China Global Times Editor tweeted that China has the market demand to buy USD 40bln-50bln worth of US farm products and that China won't make a commitment that it cannot honour in which he added that once it promises, it will fulfil. (Twitter)

 

UK/EU

There could be a second special European Council before the end of October and an agreement this week is unlikely with the summit more likely to focus on extension to 31st January 2020 or later according to a diplomatic note, while it was also reported that Irish Foreign Minister Coveney hinted an agreement may not be reachable at the EU summit this week. (BuzzFeed/RTE) Separately, Brexit deal hopes are reported to have increased as sources in both sides of the channel stated there was cautious optimism that a narrow path to a deal could now be appearing. (Telegraph)

FX 

DXY was relatively flat below 98.50 as participants second-guessed the recent trade developments and amid sideways price action across most major counterparts in which EUR/USD has stuck to a thin range, with the single currency also nearing an option expiry at 1.1020 for today’s New York cut. GBP/USD has been more turbulent amid the Brexit-related uncertainty as the earlier pressure from doubts on reaching an agreement, was eventually alleviated by reports there was cautious optimism from both sides of the channel that a narrow path to a deal could be appearing and with the EU mulling an emergency summit to get the Brexit deal done, which helped GBP/USD reclaim the 1.2600 handle. Elsewhere, USD/JPY was steady despite the outperformance of Japanese risk sentiment, while antipodeans conformed to the uninspiring picture after the RBA minutes provided little in terms of new information in which it reiterated the board is prepared to ease policy further if needed and that it is reasonable to expect that an extended period of low rates would be required.

RBA Minutes from October 1st meeting stated the board judged case for easing at October meeting outweighed arguments against a move and that it is prepared to ease policy further if needed. RBA also reiterated that it is reasonable to expect that an extended period of low rates would be required, while board members noted global trend of lower rates and discussed the possibility rate cuts could have less impact than in past but judged lower rates will still have an effect through AUD. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were lacklustre with WTI crude futures mildly pressured as the US-China trade optimism waned which pressured WTI back towards the USD 53.00/bbl level and Brent below USD 59.00/bbl, while participants will also have to wait an extra day this week for the latest inventory reports due to the Columbus Day holiday. Elsewhere, gold prices were little changed due to the uneventful greenback with the precious metal biding its time just south of the USD 1500/oz level and copper mirrored the indecisive risk tone due to the tempered trade hopes which had subsequently pressured Chinese commodity prices from the open.

GEOPOLITICS US President Trump is to authorise sanctions against current and former Turkish officials, while the US will immediately stop negotiations with Turkey on a USD 100bln trade deal and are to reintroduce steel tariffs back at 50%. (Newswires) US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said the US sanctioned Turkey’s Ministers of Interior, Defence and Energy but added the US will issue license to continue to let Turkey buy fuel and will remove sanctions based on Turkey's actions. (Newswires)

US VP Pence said President Trump spoke with Turkish President Erdogan and asked him to halt incursion into Syria, while Erdogan gave assurance that Turkey will not attack the city of Kobani. Furthermore, Pence said he will visit the region to seek a ceasefire and that no decision has been made on whether the scheduled Trump-Erdogan meeting next month will take place. (Newswires)

US

Conditions were thin in the North American trade, with many players away on US Columbus Day and Canadian Thanksgiving. However, the positivity seen on Friday has been faded, as desks re-evaluate the optimism over US/China trade talks and challenges around the course for Brexit deal emerge. With that said, the usually hawkish Global Times editor has tried to explain away some of the differences in language used by the US/China over the weekend, while many Brexit watchers were never truly convinced that UK PM Johnson's plan would be able to fly in its current form. And then on the margin, geopolitics around Turkey/Syria have been at the forefront of traders’ minds which left the equity complex which largely flat, while T-Note futures finished up (settling 11 ticks higher at 130-07, though off the pre-market highs seen after reports that China wanted more discussions before signing the phase one trade deal).

Other News - China reportedly limited the use of proceeds from privately-placed bonds approved after September 19th, in which it requires a Co. to use part of the proceeds to repay its existing bonds if the amount of new issuance is more than 40% of its net asset value. (Newswires)

HKMA - Hong Kong Monetary Authority said it would cut the amount of capital that banks need to set aside for the first time since 2015 in which the city's countercyclical capital buffer (CCB) will be reduced to 2% from 2.5%. (Newswires)

Trade

US-China talks are to resume next week and the Phase 1 could be wrapped up in November according to China press, while it was earlier reported that China wants more discussions before signing the Phase 1 deal with US President Trump. (Newswires/SCMP)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said US and China have a fundamental agreement that is subject to documentation and that they are working with China to achieve a signing in Chile in which he expects that the sides will have a deal. Mnuchin stated that both sides have agreed there needs to be a dispute resolution system and that there are a number of words which need to be agreed regarding enforcement, while he added there will be deputy level calls this week and a principal level call next week but also stated the expectation is that if there is not a deal by mid-December, then the December 15th tariffs will be implemented. (Newswires)

China Global Times Editor tweeted that trade talks made a breakthrough last week and the sides have strong will to reach a deal, while he noted the initial Chinese comments were moderate which does not mean that China’s real attitude is not positive. Global Times Editor also stated that China has the market demand to buy USD 40bln-50bln worth of US farm products and that China won't make a commitment that it cannot honour in which he added that once it promises, it will fulfil. (Twitter)

A China state media blog believes the language discrepancies between US and China is because of all the prior 'flip flops' and that all indications show China are not feeling a firm agreement is in place, while China is also said to think 'Phase 1' of the deal was not balanced according to CNBC's Yoon. Furthermore, a separate CNBC reporter stated that another round of in-person US-China negotiations is likely considering how many variables remain in concluding Phase 1. (CNBC)

subject: RBA Minutes from October 1st meeting states board judged case for easing at October meeting outweighed arguments against a move and that the board is prepared to ease policy further if needed
content:
Says:

  • Reasonable to expect extended period of low rates would be required.
  • Board members noted global trend of lower rates.
  • Discussed possibility rate cuts could have less impact than in past but judged lower rates will still have an effect through AUD.

subject: PREVIEW: RBA minutes from the October 1st meeting where the central bank lowered rates by 25bps to a fresh record low of 0.75% as expected, due at 0130BST/1930CDT/0830HKT
content:
At the meeting, the RBA lowered the Cash Rate Target to 0.75% as expected and reiterated it is reasonable to expect that an extended period of low interest rates will be required in Australia to reach full employment and achieve the inflation target, but added that a gentle turning point appears to have been reached.

RBA also stated the economy still has spare capacity and lower interest rates will help make inroads into that, while the board will continue to monitor developments including in the labour market and is prepared to ease monetary policy further if needed to support sustainable growth in the economy, full employment and the achievement of the inflation target over time. However, it also noted that the low level of interest rates, recent tax cuts, ongoing spending on infrastructure, signs of stabilisation in some established housing markets and a brighter outlook for the resources sector should all support growth.

The initial reaction in AUD/USD to the rate announcement was to the upside as the statement added that a gentle turning point appears to have been reached, although this was eventually pared as the central bank also noted it is reasonable to expect an extended period of low interest rates will be required, that it has room to further ease if needed and that risks are titled to the downside.
